SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Class CouplingManager

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.CouplingManager
public final class CouplingManager extends Object
A utility class that manages coupling (attachment) between locomotives and carriages.

What is a utility class?

This is a FINAL class with a PRIVATE constructor, which means:

  • You cannot create instances of this class (private constructor)
  • You cannot extend/inherit from this class (final keyword)
  • All methods are static (called on the class itself, not on objects)

Example of utility class usage: 

 // You DON'T do this:
 CouplingManager manager = new CouplingManager();  // ERROR! Constructor is private
 
 // You DO this instead:
 CouplingManager.enforceCoupling(locomotive);  // Call static method directly on class

Purpose:

This class was originally designed to make attached carriages follow a locomotive smoothly at the pixel level. However, in the current version (v5.11.22), this functionality has been DISABLED because carriages now move naturally via the master-slave attachment system in Vehicle.

The method is kept for potential future use or reference, but currently does nothing.

See Also:
  • Locomotive
  • Carriage
  • Vehicle.attachVehicle(Vehicle)

  • Method Details

    • enforceCoupling

      public static void enforceCoupling(Locomotive loco)
      Enforces smooth coupling between a locomotive and its attached carriages.

      CURRENT STATUS: DISABLED (v5.11.22)

      This method is currently disabled and does nothing. In previous versions, it attempted to make carriages follow the locomotive smoothly using pixel-level calculations. However, this approach caused problems:

      • v5.11.16-18: Complex calculations led to erratic carriage behavior
      • v5.11.20-21: Simple forward movement still didn't work properly

      The solution: Carriages now move naturally through the master-slave attachment system in the Vehicle class. They don't need independent movement logic - they stay in their attached positions and move only when the locomotive naturally pulls them via the coupling connection.

      This method is kept in case future versions need a different coupling approach, but currently it intentionally does nothing.

      Parameters:
      loco - the locomotive whose carriages should be managed (currently unused)
